jgame

Class ImageCache

  • java.lang.Object
    • jgame.ImageCache

  • public class ImageCache
extends java.lang.Object
    A cache for images in a game.
    Author:
    William Chargin

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description

      The cache of file names to objects.

      The default image cache, used for static convenience methods.

      The prefix for filenames passed to this cache.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors

      Creates the image cache with the given filename prefix, and sets the cache as the default cache.

      • getImage

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage getImage(java.lang.String fileName)
        Gets the cached object with the given filename from the default cache. If the object does not yet exist, it will be cached and returned.
        Parameters:
        fileName - the relevant file name
        Returns:
        the generated object

      • getSequentialImages

        public static java.util.List<java.awt.Image> getSequentialImages(java.lang.String prefix,
                                                                 int start,
                                                                 int end,
                                                                 java.lang.String suffix)
        Gets images in sequential order from the default cache. This method does not include leading zeroes. For example, a set of images named image1.png, image2.png, and image3.png could be retrieved with a call to: 
         getSequentialImages("image", 1, 3, ".png");
        Parameters:
        prefix - the prefix before the numbers
        start - the number to start at (inclusive)
        end - the number to end at (inclusive)
        suffix - the suffix after the numbers (should include file extension)
        Returns:
        a list of the images matching the criteria
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any of the images could not be found
        Since:
        1.2

      • getSequentialImages

        public static java.util.List<java.awt.Image> getSequentialImages(java.lang.String prefix,
                                                                 int start,
                                                                 int end,
                                                                 java.lang.String suffix,
                                                                 int zeroDecimal)
        Gets the images in sequential order from the default cache. This method includes a given number of leading zeroes. For example, a set of images named image09.png , image10.png, and image11.png could be retrieved with a call to: 
         getSequential("image", 9, 11, ".png", 1);
        This can be passed directly to a GSprite constructor to create an animated sprite: 
         GSprite spr = new GSprite(cache.getSequential("image", 9, 11, ".png", 1));
        Parameters:
        prefix - the prefix before the numbers
        start - the number to start at (inclusive)
        end - the number to end at (inclusive)
        suffix - the suffix after the numbers (should include file extension)
        zeroDecimal - the decimal place to be zero-filled use this if you have images labeled, for example, image0001.png instead of just image1.png. The precise handling of leading zeroes is such that the numbered portion of the file name will always have length greater than this argument. For example, with this argument set to 2, the number 7 would be transformed to 007 and 81 would become 081, while 123 and 5678 would be unaffected. You can think of this argument as the number of zeroes to prepend to any single digit number to force the resultant string into a valid format.
        Returns:
        a list of the images matching the criteria
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any of the images could not be found
        Since:
        1.2

      • getSequentialSprite

        public static GSprite getSequentialSprite(java.lang.String prefix,
                                          int start,
                                          int end,
                                          java.lang.String suffix)
        Creates a sprite with the images in sequential order. This method does not include leading zeroes. For example, a sprite with the set of images named image1.png, image2.png, and image3.png could be retrieved with a call to: 
         getSequentialSprite("image", 1, 3, ".png");
        Parameters:
        prefix - the prefix before the numbers
        start - the number to start at (inclusive)
        end - the number to end at (inclusive)
        suffix - the suffix after the numbers (should include file extension)
        Returns:
        a list of the images matching the criteria
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any of the images could not be found
        Since:
        1.2

      • getSequentialSprite

        public static GSprite getSequentialSprite(java.lang.String prefix,
                                          int start,
                                          int end,
                                          java.lang.String suffix,
                                          int zeroDecimal)
        Creates a sprite with the images in sequential order. This method does not include leading zeroes. For example, a sprite with the set of images named image1.png, image2.png, and image3.png could be retrieved with a call to: 
         getSequentialSprite("image", 1, 3, ".png");
        Parameters:
        prefix - the prefix before the numbers
        start - the number to start at (inclusive)
        end - the number to end at (inclusive)
        suffix - the suffix after the numbers (should include file extension)
        zeroDecimal - the decimal place to be zero-filled use this if you have images labeled, for example, image0001.png instead of just image1.png. The precise handling of leading zeroes is such that the numbered portion of the file name will always have length greater than this argument. For example, with this argument set to 2, the number 7 would be transformed to 007 and 81 would become 081, while 123 and 5678 would be unaffected. You can think of this argument as the number of zeroes to prepend to any single digit number to force the resultant string into a valid format.
        Returns:
        a list of the images matching the criteria
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any of the images could not be found
        Since:
        1.2

        public static GSprite getSprite(java.lang.String fileName)

        Returns:
        the generated object

      • getSequential

        public java.util.List<java.awt.Image> getSequential(java.lang.String prefix,
                                                    int start,
                                                    int end,
                                                    java.lang.String suffix)
                                             throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Gets the images in sequential order. This method does not include leading zeroes and is equivalent to calling getSequential(String, int, int, String, int) with a zeroDecimal argument of 0. For example, a set of images named image1.png, image2.png, and image3.png could be retrieved with a call to: 
         getSequential("image", 1, 3, ".png");
        This can be passed directly to a GSprite constructor to create an animated sprite: 
         GSprite spr = new GSprite(cache.getSequential("image", 1, 3, ".png"));
        Parameters:
        prefix - the prefix before the numbers
        start - the number to start at (inclusive)
        end - the number to end at (inclusive)
        suffix - the suffix after the numbers (should include file extension)
        Returns:
        a list of the images matching the criteria
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any of the images could not be found
        Since:
        1.2

      • getSequential

        public java.util.List<java.awt.Image> getSequential(java.lang.String prefix,
                                                    int start,
                                                    int end,
                                                    java.lang.String suffix,
                                                    int zeroDecimal)
                                             throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Gets the images in sequential order. This method includes a given number of leading zeroes. For example, a set of images named image09.png , image10.png, and image11.png could be retrieved with a call to: 
         getSequential("image", 9, 11, ".png", 1);
        This can be passed directly to a GSprite constructor to create an animated sprite: 
         GSprite spr = new GSprite(cache.getSequential("image", 9, 11, ".png", 1));
        Parameters:
        prefix - the prefix before the numbers
        start - the number to start at (inclusive)
        end - the number to end at (inclusive)
        suffix - the suffix after the numbers (should include file extension)
        zeroDecimal - the decimal place to be zero-filled use this if you have images labeled, for example, image0001.png instead of just image1.png. The precise handling of leading zeroes is such that the numbered portion of the file name will always have length greater than this argument. For example, with this argument set to 2, the number 7 would be transformed to 007 and 81 would become 081, while 123 and 5678 would be unaffected. You can think of this argument as the number of zeroes to prepend to any single digit number to force the resultant string into a valid format.
        Returns:
        a list of the images matching the criteria
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if any of the images could not be found
        Since:
        1.2

      • remove

        public java.awt.Image remove(java.lang.String fileName)
        Removes the image with the given name from the cache.
        Parameters:
        fileName - the name of the file to remove
        Returns:
        the image that was removed, or null if none existed

      • setPrefix

        public void setPrefix(java.lang.String prefix)
        Sets the filename prefix for this cache. Imagehis will only affect cache objects that have not yet begun loading.
        Parameters:
        prefix - the new prefix, or null to clear the prefix
